element_texts.text: Journal of the Commissioners of the United States, appointed to hold conferences with the several Nations of Indians South of the Ohio Commenced by Colo Hawkins one of the Commrs  On the 18th July He received from the Secy of War the following letter at Tookaubatchee dated War Dept, 18 June 1801.  Sir  The president of the United States having appointed you a commissioner, jointly with William R Davie and James Wilkinson Esquires to hold conferences with several of the Indian Nations, South of Ohio, you are requested to repair to South West point in the state of Tennessee by the first day of August next there to meet your colleagues, the first named] of whom will be the bearer of your commissions and Instructions

the red and white people dwelling in it live in the bonds of brotherhood and friendship.  To aid in perpetuating this highly desirable object, the President has directed three of his beloved Men to meet your principal Men at South West point in the State of Tennessee an the first day of august.  next: He requests you to send such of your chiefs and principal Men as you have full confidence in, then & there to meet the Commissioners; and that you will impower them to state for the consideration of Government all that you have upon your mind, to hear in behalf of your nation all that those Commissioners shall have to propose and to unclear to such proposals as the Commissioners shall make, and your Representatives shall conceive to be proper and usefull.  Given at the War Office of the US.  this eighteenth day of June  AD 1801  Henry Dearborn  Secretary of War --"  left side of page has hand-drawn sketch of 13-point star representing seal bearing letters:  LS  Colo Meigs delivered to Colo Hawkins two packets from the Secretary of War containing the Commissions and Instructions to James Williamson Brigr General in the Service of the United States, Benjamin Hawkins of North Carolina and Andrew Pickens of South Carolina

and commence the business of your missions [[right side signature: I  am [two words unclear] Henry Dearborn]] left side signature, lower:  Benjn Hawkins Esqr  Agent, I.A. St. Ohio  4th August  Colo Hawkins arrived at South West Point & Colo Meigs Agent for the Cherokees informed him that on the 11th July he sent the following Address "To the Chiefs and Warriors of the Cherokees -- Friends and Brothers  The President of the US takes you by the hand and invites you and all the nations of red people within the territory of the United States to look up to him as their Father and friend: to rely in full confidence on his unvarying disposition to lead and protect them in the paths of peace and harmony, and to cultivate friendship with his brothers of the Same colour, and  with the Citizens of the United States.  The Chain of Friendship is now bright & binds us together, for your and our sakes, and for the Sakes of your and our Children, we must prevent it from becoming rusty; so long as the mountains in our land shall endure and our Rivers flow, so long may the

having agreed among themselves that it was necessary that the Chiefs of the Nations about to convein and consult prior to their meeting with the Commissioners of the United States, they communicated their opinion to the Little Turkey the Chief of the Nation who concurred in opinion with them and sent runners through the Nation to invite the Chiefs to assemble at Oostenauleh on the 18th of this month to consult together accordingly.  But before this the invitation sent by Colo Meigs had been received and several of the Chiefs have attended here and with them some sent by the Little Turkey to take the Commissioners by the hand and welcome them to the lands.  The meeting at Oostenaulel will unavoidably derange the periods pointed out by you for the other conferences, as the one contemplated to be held here cannot be closed till the last of this month.  I have been very unwell for some days past, am getting better and but just able to attend to business -- I have the honor to be &c  Benjamin Hawkins  bottom left, addressee:  The Honble Henry Dearborn Secy of War

Carolina or any two of them to hold Conferences with the Cherokees, Chickasaws, Choctaws and Creeks and to conclude and sign treaties with them. --  7th August  Several Chiefs from the Towns on the Tennessee called on Colo Hawkins and has a long conversation with him on the affairs of their Nation.  They stated the improvements made in the products of the Country, that a total change had taken place in the habits of the nation since the introduction of the plan for their civilization; that a desire for individual property was very prevalent and that the current of conversations now to acquire it, by attention to stock, to farming and to manufactures.)  Colo Hawkins wrote the following letter to the Secy of War dated South West Point  7 Aug. 1801 --  I traveled through the upper Creeks and Cherokees and arrived here on the 4th of this month where I received your packet containing the commissions and instructions for the Commissioners.  My colleagues have not arrived --  Colo Meigs had taken measures to find your address of the 18th June to the Indians.  Some time after this, the deputation sent by the Cherokees to the seat of Government arrived, who having

home. As we are determined to concur in every thing agreed upon between you, and the old Chiefs soon to convene at Oostenauleh, there is no necessity for our remaining here; and as we have manifested our respect for the new President by our immediate attention to his invitation--.  One thing we mention for your information -- there is a division now among ourselves -- we have thought seriously of it, and it is right that you should know it.  We leave to the Chiefs to convene at Oostenauleh the Government of our Country as they think proper, which lies on the other side of the Chilhowe Mountains; we shall govern that part to the Chiefs. --  We have one thing to say to your as agent for indian Affairs which you will hear a style of complaint from four of the other chiefs, they say we have had more Wheels and Cards than our share, and in consequence we are more

10th August  Weele, John Watts and Double Head with several of the other Chiefs called on Colo Hawkins and delivered this Talk in behalf of themselves and the Chiefs of the River Towns.  "Colonl Meigs sent us the Invitation of the President to come and meet his Commissioners here on the 1st of this month, we have come accordingly and we have with us a representation from our part of the Nation.  We have been here several days, waiting for the arrival of the Commissioners, you are come but we cannot hear of your colleagues and it appears now quite uncertain when you will have a meeting.  The Chiefs who are to convene at Oostenauleh sent us unclear an invitation to go there, of course we suppose they have no need of our council.  We will return home.  We have taken the letter of the President, from soon after your first coming among us, and as you have come through our nation you can see and know we have done so.  so shall now return home

to my Agency:  His successor Mr Adams was authorized by the Laws of the United States to persue the same course; and he continued me as he found me, the Agent for carrying into effect the benevolent views of the Government in relation to you red people.  By the constitution of the US. the Office of the President is during the term of four years.  This Man stood high in the estimation of the people of the US. when they elected him president; but on mature deliberation they have altered their opinion of Mr Adams and would not elect him again to that office.  Mr. Jefferson is the Man of their choice, he is their president and your New Father, he is every way worthy of the high trust confided to him by his fellow Citizens and of your entire confidence, your love and

more advanced in making our own clothing as well as in farming than they -- The fact is this, the offer of these things was made to all of us at the same time, we accepted of it, some of us, immediately and others soon after, those who complain came in late, we have got the start of them which we are determined to keep.--"  the reply  Your attention to the invitation sent by your father the President to meet his Commissioners here does you credit, He is a new Father to you, made so by the choice of the American people -- This benevolent care of the Government was confided by him to

made by them to you will manifest a fair and candid attention to your rights; you will be treated as a free people, under the guarantee and benevolent care of the american people; nothing will be asked of you without offering you an equivalent and whatever is asked of you, you are advised to weigh well before you answer, and always keep this in view; you are a free people under the guarantee of the Government of the United States, that you have for several years had daily & substantial proofs of the benevolent care of the Government, by the protection of your rights by a strong and expensive enititay? establishment, by the introduction at a considerable expense of the Wheel, Loom &

veneration.  From such a Man you red people have every thing to hope and nothing to fear.  I cannot say when the Commissioners will be here.  By the papers I have received since my arrival, they were expected to be here ten days past and I expect one or both of them daily -- One of the Gentlemen named to you declined coming, resigned his appointment and General Pickens your old friend is in his place.  If one comes, two us us will proceed to execute the duties of our Mission and it will be as effectual as if we were all present.  I can now only tell you, you may have entire confidence in my Colleagues, that you have nothing to fear from such Men, that all propositions

early to the benefits arising from the plan for bettering your condition; That you have got the start of the other Towns should not be a subject of complaint on their part, but a stimulous, as they now see your prosperity from the experiment among yourselves.  When they complain, tell them come on, you are a head of them now, but to double their diligence and they may overtake you.  14 August  L. unclear 14 Augt. 1801.  I wrote on the 7th. to inform you of any arrival here on the 4h of this month -- I am now recovered from my late indisposition and able to attend to the duties of my mission.  A waggon arrived here yesterday with some public stores for the Commissioners.  We have received no accounts to be relied on respecting my colleagues --  I have the honor &c  Benjn Hawkins -- left bottom, addressee:  The Honble  The Secy of War

and plough into your land; and that if you can accommodate a people who do so much for you, and who mean to continue their good offers to you whether you attend to their wants or not, you ought to weigh well, to deliberate long, and to have substantial reasons to offer before you say no, to any propositions made to you by the Commissioners, when some will be made without offering you an equivalent.  If you return home you must have some men who possess your entire confidence to join the other chiefs of the Nation who we may expect from the Council at Oostenauleh.  Your nation must not divide you must be one people under the Government of your old Chiefs -- As to the complaint you mention it is very agreeable to me, I am glad that the people of your towns attended early

listen to it attentively and let it sink deep in your hearts.  It is the same speach which has been sent out to you by your Agent Colo Meigs.  The people of the US having given you a new father, we have pleasure informing you that he holds his red Children and his White Children in the same regard, that that he will neither violate your lands or suffer them to be violated while you behave yourselves as you have done like dutifull and affectionate children who look up to him for protection.  But it is our duty also to tell you, that your father the president will expect you to pay prompt regard to this his first invitation to wait us at this place which he has appointed for the purpose and where provisions and necessities are strikeout:  provided collected.  Your father has a

The morning of this day General Wilkinson arrived --  15h August  The Commissioners proceeded to execute the duties of their Mission -- being informed that some of the Chiefs were opposed to meeting the Commissioners at this place and had perhaps Tellico and that there was some discontent and division among the Chiefs on the propriety of the Meeting at Oostenauleh after they had received the invitation of the President to convene at this place -- They wrote and sent the following letter by an interpreter express to the Chiefs about to convene at Oostenauleh.  To the Chiefs and Warriors of the Cherokee Nation  We send you under cover a talk from our beloved great Chief and father Thomas Jefferson president of the US.  We beg of you to open your Ears, and to listen

16th August.  At the special request of a Delegation? from the Towns on the Tennessee below this the Commissioners wrote and delivered to them to be sent under their direction this address -- To the Chiefs & Warriors of the Cherokee Nation of Indians on the Tennessee  The Talks from your father the President was sent you by Colo Meigs your Agent, inviting you to send such Chiefs and Principal Men as you have full confidence in to meet his Commissioners at this place on the first of the Month, to state for the Consideration of Government all that you have upon your minds, to hear in behalf of your nation all that the Commissioners have to propose and to agree to such proposals as they shall make and your representatives shall

a right to name the place where he will speak to you and you have no right to object to his invitation, since he has for object your own goods, as well as that of his White Children.  We do therefore confidently expect you will be on your feet so soon as you receive this talk, and that we shall have the happiness to take you by the hand on the 25th of the present Month, that is ten days from this day -- We urge this injunction upon you because our business calls us elsewhere --  We are your friend and the   Representatives of your father  the president  Ja Wilkinson  Benjamin Hawkins  left bottom, address:  South West point  15 Augt 1801

Colo Meigs the Agent for the Cherokees communicated to the Commissioners a letter from Mr Hooker US factor at Tellico of the 15th informing that an Indian Woman was killed on Stock Creek in Knox County on the 12th inst. referring him to Capt Flanmagan as for the Particulars.  The Commissioners requested the Agent to send an express immediately to the Gentleman referred to for the particulars and they wrote to the Governor this Letter  South West point 16th Aug 1801  At this time that we do ourselves the pleasure to announce to your Excellency our arrival here as Commissioners of the US. for the purpose of holding a conference with the Cherokees on subjects interesting to our fellow Citizens, We have to lament and

shall conceive to be proper and usefull --  We two of the Commissioners of the United States are now arrived, and have sent to your Council convened at Oostenauleh to attend here on the 25th. inst. and as we understand from some of your most distinguished Chiefs that you not be at the Meeting of Oostenauleh, we have proposed  to them to send runners to invite you to attend here on the day appointed when we shall expect and be glad to see you for the purposes expressed in the Talk of the President.  We are your friends &  the friends of your Nation  Ja. Wilkinson  Benjamin Hawkins  left bottom, address: S.W. point  16 Augt. 1801

ere this --  We have the honor to be &c  Ja. Wilkinson  Benjamin Hawkins  on left, address:  His Excellency  John Levier  Governor of Tennessee  The family of the murdered woman sent a runner to the Chiefs at S.W. point, to inform them of the murder, and that the woman left a young Child not four months old.  And to request their advice after they had consulted the Commissioners of the United States how they were to ask  The Commissioners communicated what they had learned and down? to the Chiefs and made fresh observations on the transaction as were suited to the occasion -- 18 au  The Commissioners taking a

and regret a most wicked and barbarous murder perpetrated on Stock Creek in Knox  County on the body of an Indian woman who was with her young child and a part of her family on the way to Knoxville seeking a market for the products of her industry.  Your Excellency knows as well the effect this will have on the minds of the Indians as the necessity there is of a speedy exertion of the Competent authority to bring with the least possible delay the Offender to justice; and we must request your interposition to produce that desirable end.  The particulars of this transaction have not reached us -- We are referred to a Capt Flanagan near Knoxville who is mentioned to us as a man in estimation for them, as you are near him we presume you have received them

the time fixed for the Conference with that Nation.  I have in consequence dispatched an express to you to apprise you of it and to inform you, that you may expect the Commissioners at the Bluff by the last of September or early in october  I request you to communicate this without delay to the Chiefs and Warriors of the Chickasaws and to inform them that as soon as the Comrs can fix on the day for meeting them they will be informed of it.  I have sent you a letter to Colo John W Kee which you will forward by express to prevent a like disappointment with the Choctaws --  I am Sir &c  Benjamin Hawkins  Agent for Indian affairs  South of Ohio  left bottom, address:  W Saml Mitchell  Agent for the Chickasaws

thorough view of the duties enjoined by their Mission & being of opinion that the delays here would unavoidably derange the Conference contemplated to be held with the Chickasaws and Choctaws & determined to prevent all unnecessary expenses to place both of these conferences under their control and for that and sent a Steady Cherokee Runner with the following letter to the Agents of the Chickasaws and Choctaws  South West point  18 August. 1801 -- General Wilkinson an Mr Hawkins, two of the Commissioners of the US appointed to hold conferences &c with the Indian Nations South of Ohio are now here and as they will be delayed longer with the Cherokees than was expected by the President they cannot be at the Chickasaw Bluff by this

bourhood, taking care to designate the Species and quantity.  It is proposed to hold a conference with the Chickasaws at the post  of your command toward the end of next month, and the Contractor has been required to furnish rations for the purpose, but as he has failed I am fearful he may be deficient in this instance and I send this express to be certain of the fact by you that I may in case of his default take measures to process a supply before I leave the Ohio.  The bearer is to return in season to meet me at the mouth of bear Creek, I therefore request you to furnish provisions and to dispatch unclear without a moments unnecessary delay.  I

a similar letter was written to Colo John W Kee  Agent of the Choctaws.  The Contents of both these letters was communicated to the runner and to prevent as much as possible the failure of the object, the letters were in the absence of the agents to be opened by the Interpreters or Chiefs. & The General to the Commandant at the Bluff, respecting supplies  Head Quarters S.W. point 18h Augt 1801  Sir, You will be pleased to inform me by the Bearer what may be your actual situation in regard to provisions, and what may be your expectations, with the grounds on which such expectations are founded. -- You will be pleased  also to inform me, whether provisions could in any extremity be suddenly procured in your neighbour

on the propriety of the meeting at Oostenauleh after they had received the invitation of the president to convene at this place we wrote the address No 1 and sent it by an interpreter to the Chiefs convened at that Town.  After this on a consultation with some chiefs of the Towns on Tennessee we wrote and sent under their direction 2.  The Same day having received the account 3. of the murder of an indian woman in the Neighbourhood of Knoxville we wrote 4. and sent it by express to the governor of this state and directed Colo Meigs Agent for the Cherokees to take measures immediately to obtain the particulars of this transaction.  Taking thorough view of all the Dates

expect to leave this place about the 5th. of next month -- With Consideration & esteem  I am &c  Ja Wilkinson  left side address:  Capt Sparks  3d Regt.  The Commissioners then wrote the following letter to the Honble the Secy of War --  General Wilkinson arrived here on the evening of the 14h and we proceeded to immediately execute the duties of our Mission.  Being informed that Some of the Chiefs were opposed to meeting the Commissioners at this place and have proposed Tellico; and that there was Some discontent and division among the Chiefs

23d August  The messenger sent by the Commiss. to Oostenauleh of the 15h.  He reported that hje delivered the talk sent by him and had it correctly interpreted to the Chiefs, that after this they consulted among themselves and prepared an answer, which was to have been sent but on further reflection was altered to the one sent, which he delivered to the Commissioners; that of himself he told the Chiefs the Provision was made at S.W. point for the Meeting which could not be transported in time from there to Tellico; that he understood that the first answer was neither respectful nor friendly.  The Answer Oostenauleh 19 Augt. 1801  Brothers the Commisss. of the US.  Your express arrived at a time when.

at Tellico, but whether for the Trade or the purpose contemplated in the conferences here, we are not informed.  General Wilkinson who came here by the way of Wilkinsonville is of opinion that the Stores goods and provisions intended to be sent down for the conferences at the Chickasaw Bluff and the Natchez will not reach the first point before the beginning of November because of the lowness of the waters and the consequent impediment to the navigation of the Ohio.  We have the honor to be  &c &c &c &c  Ja Wilkinson  Benjamin Hawkins  at left, address:  The Honble  Henry Dearborn  Secy of War  References  left column:  No 1 Sec 15h Augt.  2 " 16h "  3 Mr Hooker 16h.  right column:  No Sec letter to Gov. Davies  4 to Mitchell  5 ' W Kee  6 Capt Sparks.

Beloved Commissioners  One of our people is missing? & fell, but we expect the Commissioners will look about them and have that bad action repaired by apprehending & punishing the aggressor before we meet.  We expect our friends the Commisss will use their best endeavors to bring the Murderers to light and punishment, that the authority of leading and wise men may not be trampled on.  You will see us in twelve nights at Tellico, if that place should be agreeable to you, you will see us there.  With sentiments of great regard for the Commis  I remain yr friend & brother  The unclear in behalf and at the request of the meeting.

when our Council was setting, and are glad to hear from you -- We suppose we have or ought to have a right to have something to say in choosing the place of Conference.  Tellico is the place where we are used to meet and that is the place we expect you will will meet us. -- Our nation is much scattered and it will take up time before we can communicate to the different towns the time that may be convenient to all to meet. --  Tellico is our beloved ground, and more convenient for our nation, besides the range there is much better, whereas about the point there is nothing for horses.  Beloved

as well as the present procedure they did not comprehend --  They hoped the Commissioners would not take any definitive for the present; that Ne,ne,too,yuah, would go himself to the Chief about to assemble at Tellico and advise them to come immediately on their arrival"  25h. August  S. W. point 25 Augt. 1801.  Sir,   Since our last of the 18h inst we have received from the Cherokees assembled at Oostenauleh the talk you will find undercover, indication of a degree of presumption which must not be indulged; this being the spot assigned by the Prest. for the Conference and the provisions being deposited here.  Could we have the impolicy

24th August  The Commissioners communicated the answer which they had received to the Chiefs from the River towns who were with them.   Two of them Chu,quilatague / Double Head / and Ne,ne,too,yuh / the Bloody Fellow / seemed much concerned and said "This is unusual and contrary to our expectations; the invitation from our father the president is to meet his Commissioners at this place and here the Commissioners have made the requisite provisions, to move this will cause an additional and unnecessary expense -- If the Indians have provisions of their own it would be another thing they have not, that this plan is as convenient as Tellico and they have food sufficient at this season for their horses that the meeting at Oostenauleh

Perhaps it may not be amiss for us to remark at this time, that we apprehend the assembling of the Choctaw Nation at the Town of Natchez near the center of population in that district, will expose the inhabitants to much unavoidable vexation and abuse of property and the indians to the debouchery inseparable from our frontier villages --  We therefore beg leave to submit to the Executive consideration the expedience of naming a different place for the Conference or of authorising us to do so.  Shoud any communication to us on this subject be deemed necessary it can be forwarded from fort Washington (Cincinnati) by the Commanding officer there to the Cantonment on the Ohio, and from thence

impolicy of the step, we should not consider ourselves at Liberty to change the Ground under circumstances of increased expenses and delay.  We shall therefore mildly but friendly admonish the Chiefs who may assemble at Tellico of the impropriety inadmissability of their pretensions and again invite them to attend the Conference here at that day, in which measure we shall have the concurrence of Double Head and Bloody Fellow two of the most conspicuous chiefs who reside near the Tennessee below and are now with us.  We believe our business when once begun may be compleated in a few days after which we shall send a runner to convince the Chickasaws & will proceed by water with out delay to the point of interview. about to assemble at that place, which he enjoined on them to deliver immediately on their arrival.  All the Indians who were waiting the Conference with the Commissioners showed much uneasiness at the mode of procedure on their part.  31st  Chas. Hicks an Interpreter who attended the Meeting at Oostenauleh made this report.  The Chiefs at Oostenauleh conducted their business in secrecy? Seemed to distress him as he was in the public Service and withheld every thing from him, as in their power.  It appeared to him, the Chiefs were devious of unclear and attempting to exercise the right of removing the public Agents and In

thence in season to overtake us at the bluffs and enable us to give change to the Rendezvous proposed for the Choctaws without inconvenience or delay.  We have yet no information respecting Goods intended for the conference at this place, but we do not propose to halt for them and we are sorry to add that we understand the murderer of the Cherokee woman on Stock Creek has escaped from the country, the perpetrator is generally believed to be Peter Whales said to be of bad character  We are with sentiments &  Ja Wilkinson  Benjamin Hawkins  left, address: the secy of War  N.B. We hear nothing of Genl Pickens  30h. August.  Ninetooyuh reported to the Comms that he had been at Tellico and delivered a strong talk to the Bark for the Chiefs about

attended there appeared an intention in James Van and some others to replace the major in the Agency, he could not being excluded hear the proposition distinctly, but he heard the major reply "That he would not now accept of it"  He is at a loss to know whence this conduct among the Chiefs originated.  1st Sept. 1801.  The Commissioners sent the following address to the Chiefs about to assemble at Tellico.  Brothers, In addition to the talk delivered at the Bank by the Bloody fellow we think it proper to inform you that having waited here 17 days to meet you in conference arguably the

Interpreters; that the evening after they red the talk from the Commissioners they proposed and prepaired  strikeout of two words an censure in his opinion rude and improper, among other things.  They said that when the Commissioners of the US. would inform them they had the murderer of the Indian woman / murdered on the 12h on Stock Creek near Knoxville / in custody and would execute him in their presence they would attend and not till then. --  The next day on considering this part of the answer they determined to alter it and send a respectful one, which was done by the Glap? and one or two only.  In the course of the Conference at which Mr Lewis the late Agent

to meet these beloved Men whom he has appointed to confer with you -- you will deprive him of the power to serve you, and must not expect either his friends life or his protection  Brothers,   We have given you our advice the good and bad are before you and you are men so can chose for yourselves.  If you consider the friendship and protection of the presidents of the US. unclear to you then come forward to this place without loss of time.  If you do not need his protection of friendship & can live alone without him we expect you will like men and warriors speak & declare it.  Brothers, We have waited long for you and we now feel it our duty to tell you, that if you are not here within four days from this

the invitation of your father Thos Jefferson the president of the US. which was delivered to you by Colo Meigs the agent of War on the 13h. ultmen  We can but express our surprise that you should not have appeared before this time  Brothers,  We are sorry that you manifest so little respect to the voice of your New father who is as able and as desirous to foster you and to protect your interests as his predeassors. We are Sorry that you should should be so preverse and foolish as to set up your will against that of your father the president of the Sixteen fires who alone is able to defend you against your enemies --  Brothers  We are your friends and are solicitous for your happiness -- We therefore hope you will no longer turn a deaf ear to the voice of your father the president.  For if you shut your ears against his councils and refuse

talk from the Chiefs here to the people of Chilhouse, which they request you to have interpreted in like manner.  I am with much esteem & regard  Sir Yr Obt  Benjamin Hawkins left address: John W Hooker US Factor Tellico  ---  South West Point Sept. 1st. 1801  Sir  To gain all thje time possible for an answer to our proposition respecting the Conference to be held with the Choctaws we took the liberty to address the original of the enclosed duplicate to the president at his seat, and are sorry to inform you, an unexpected casualty will detain it at Knoxville until the departure of the depending mail which will convey this to you -- Since

this date we shall be obliged to leave this Country without seeing you & to report your conduct to your father the President.  We are your friends and the representatives of your father the president.  Ja Wilkinson  Benjamin Hawkins  Comissn Capt near Cooste  1 Sept. 1801 --  The Commissioners of the US. have sent to your care a talk for the Chiefs about to assemble at Tellico and they request you strikeout to have it interpreted to them by Cary.  You will find that the long way's plain and unclear and by no construction intended as a threat, we mention this to put the interpreter on his guard.  You have enclosed also a short talk

our communications of the 25h ultn and of this day to the Secy of War and we hope you may approve id this deviation from the regular course of our correspondence, which we hazzard with the intent to secure time for the seasonable arrival of any order you may think proper to [[send?] us pecting the plan for holding the proposed conference with the Chactaws.  Our leter of the 25h. was intended to be sent on the day it was written in the care of a W Watson of Alexanda who informed us of his being there on the road and that he should pass near your residence.  But as we found afterwards that he would be Detained we took it back and sent it by the mail -- Our colleague Genl Pickens arrived last night.  with

We are assured that the Cherokees have proposed a general council of the four nations to be convened at Willstown about the 20h. inst at which a deputation of the Northern Nations said to be charged with tally? is to be present -- Colo Hawkins is of opinion that this measure is produced by a panic terror springing from the apprehension that they are soon to be unclear for a further relinquishment of Lands -- Colo Meigs will attend this meeting and whether it is to be held in public or private the results must soon reach us.  We have the honor to be &c  Jam Wilkinson  Benjamin Hawkins  ---  S.W. point Sept. 1. 1801  left address:  Secy of War  Understanding from the public prints that you are on a visit to Monticello we avail ourselves of the direct conveyance to intrude on you

to gether in their Grand National Council House thought proper to elect our belved Chief Thomas Jefferson to be the president of the US. in the place of Adams who had succeeded Washington.  Brothers  Open your ears.  no sooner did our new father Tho Jefferson find himself at the head of all the white people of the sixteen fires than he turned his thoughts towards his red children, who stand most in need of his care and whom he regards with the same tenderness that he does his White Children.  Brothers  Listen well and let our words sink deep into your heads.

With the highest consideration and the  most respectful attachment we have  the honor to be  unclear  your obt  JaWilkinson  Benjn Hawkins  left address:  Thos Jefferson  pres of the US.  ---  2d Sept.  Genl Pickens arrived last Evening.  4th. Sept.  The chiefs having informed  the Commissrs. they were ready to assemble when ever again thereto and to hear what they had to say to them  The Commissioners fixed on 2 oclock PM. when they all convened at the conference bower and the Commis Delivered the following address.  by Genl Wilkinson  Chiefs & Brothers  About six moons past the people of the sixteen fires assembled unclear

predesors Washington & Adams were. Brothers  Your great father the president is desirous to ameliorate your condition to advance you in independence &c provide for your permanent happiness and that of your prosterity.  His ears are always open to your complaints, when you are aggrieved and to hear the details of your wants, should you need assistance, that his good will may be epected , to address your wrongs and to relieve your sufferings.  Brothers  Two of us are known to you & we hope you have full reliance on our friendship, of the third I will only say that he has long been the friend of the red people beyond the Ohio and that his stations forbids him to deceive them or you.

your new father Thos Jefferson is equal in power to your former fathers and he is entitled to as much confidence and respect as they were; he is as able to protect you as they were and he cherishes the same disposition toward you. We have observed in all our conversations with the Chiefs from the commentary of our interviews with them, a strong repugnance to the idea of a concession of any kind which have relation to their lands, and it was discernible that the views & dispositions of the president suspected, notwithstanding the kindness and frankness so recently experienced at the feet of Government  These observations determined us in opening the Conference to explain the standing

6h September  S. West point 6h Sept. 1801.   Sir,  On the morning of of the 4h inst the Cherokee Chiefs announced to us their readiness to hear whatever the Commissioners might have to say.  We immediately met them in council and addresed them in terms adapted to the occasion to which their speaker / Double Head / made a laconic reply and the Conference phrase unclear, possibly "only endured" until yesterday when we received from the same chief, the answers from the Council appended here, which induced us to break up the Conference without accomplishing a single object of the commision.  We beg leave to refer to our minutes which are under cover for the particular conduct of the Commissioners and for the detail of the Conference, which tho unseccessful may produce happy effects on the indian mind of late much bewildered and perplexed by occurrences which they did not understand, by misrepresentations

Conference further, which by dissolving it, we not only obliged the indians but gave them an blank testimony of the consideration and Sincerity of the president.  It is with singular pleasure we have witnessed the advance of this people, in the arts of civilization.  The acquirement of individual property by agriculture improvements, by raising stock, and by domestic manufactures seems to have taken Strong hold of the Nation, and we believe, that a few years perseverince in the benificent plan, which has produced these effects, will prepare them to accommodate their white neighbors, with lands on reasonable terms.  We propose to embark the day after tomorrow for the Chickasaw Bluffs, where we are apprehensive we shall be detained unseasonably by the non arrival of the

ing of the president and to assert his dispositions and prerogatives in such stile  as appeared best calculated to remove their doubts, and distrusts and to inspire them with confidence and respect, but in unfolding the object of the Commission, we confined ourselves to General propositions as far as was practicable and held the specific views of Government in reserve, until the temper and disposition of the Council might be unequivocally demonstrated.  The decided tone of Double Head on the subject of their lands, his pathetic appeal to the justice and magnaminity of the Government, respecting the road and the pressing demands which follow from himself and from Chu,le,o,ah for the judgment of existing treaties and for the reparation of injuries recorded in blood, rendered it in our judgements unavailing and inconsistent with our instructions, to press the Conference

We found this people like all others of their kind under similar circumstances jealous of our views and alarmed for their rights of territory, but their confidence in Government had not been shaken and we experienced little difficulty in accomplishing the treaty which we

not consent to open a road from Nashville to the Tennessee, because we find the proposed route embraced by the limits of the Chickasaws which have been clearly defined in that quarter and explicitly recognized in a declaration of President Washington bearing date of the 1st. Natchez Nov. 13. 1801 --  Sir  We arrived here yesterday at noon and shall proceed in a day or two to Lofus' Heights where we expect to meet with the Choctaws on the 20h inst. agreeably to our invitation forwarded to them thro' the proper channel from the Chickasaw  Bluffs.  We have had the honor to receive the Presidents Letter dated at Monticello the 16h Sept. and we are happy to find he has been pleased to approbate our proposition respecting the change of place to for holding the treaty With the Choctaws.  We beg leave to assure you that we shall loose no time in terminating this conference which we flatter ourselves blank favorably.  Having closed our business with the Choctaws we shall after due deliberation adopt the most posible? means for convening the Creeks

the Chickasaw Country to confine themselves to the highway proposed to be opened for which end the authority of the National Legislation may be found expedient.  We have taken measures to convince the Choctaws at Loftus "Heights on the Ground of convenience and economy to the public and of accommodation to the inhabitants and we expect to meet them in council about the 20t of November.  With the highest &  Ja Wilkinson  Benj Hawkins  A Pickins.  left side address:  The Honbe  Henry Dearborn  Sect of War

Brothers,  The president of the US. invites you to look up to him as your friend and father, to rely in full confidence on his unvarying disposition to lead and protect you in the paths of peace and prosperity and to preserve concord between you and your neighbours.  In his name we promise you that you may at all times rely upon the friendship of the US. while you conduct towards the Citizens of the US and your Indian neighbours shall be peaceable honest & fair.  Brothers,  We invite you to state to us freely the Situation of your nation and what you wish on the part of your father the president to better your condition in trade, in hunting, agriculture manufactures, and stock raising, that we may represent the Same for his consideration.  We wish you to open your minds freely to us and set forth all your wishes and all your wants, that we may learn the true state of your condition -- and be able to assist you with our advice, our attention and our friendship. --  Brothers  On the part of your white brethren we have to state to you that the path from the settlements

assembled in their great national Council House, have thought proper to elect our beloved chief Thomas Jefferson to be the president of these U.States.  Brothers,  Open your ears and listen well -- your new father Jefferson who is the friend all of the red people and of humanity, finding himself at the Head of the White of the Sixteen fires, immediately turned this thoughts to the condition of his red children who stand most in need of his care and whom he regards with the affection of a good father.  Brothers, Your father the president of the US. being far removed from you by the interventions of deep rivers, high mountains and wide forests, finds it impossible to look upon you with his own eyes, or to speak to you from his own lips, he has therefore appointed to of his beloved men Col Hawkins Genl Pickins with myself to meet you in Council and to confer with you on several Subjects interesting to yourselves and to your white brethren of the Sixteen fires -- We are happy to see you -- We on his behalf and in his name take you by the hand, and we congratulate you on your safe arrival here.

in the hope that you may enable us to make an agreeable report to our common father the President of the US. and in the mean time we shall be happy to contribute to your accommodation and the good of your nation --  December 13th  The Chiefs and the Commissioners at their conference chamber, and Tus,ko,na,hopoi,e a chief of the Lower towns informed the Commissioners that there were seven chief from different Towns and he requested on their behalf that they might be heard separately that each  might speak for his own town, and that after they had spoken that the young Warriors might be heard and that the same attention be paid to their talks as would be to those of the Chiefs.  The Commissioners replied -- you will manage your affairs your own way, we will hear all of you patiently and with pleasure --  Tuskonahopoie then addressed the Commissioners,  to day I meet the Commissioners here, who

recommend that it should be traced up and marked anew, while men can be found who were present at the survey and assisted in marking it, for if all those witnesses should die before this is done, then disputes may arise between you and your White Brethren respecting the boundary and Mischief may ensue.  Brothers,  For several years past your father the president of the US. has sent you a present of goods as a token of his friendship which will be continued the present year.  But you must recollect that you have never given an equivalent for this strong evidence of his paternal regard, and you must bear in mind that you are indebted for it to his generosity more than to his justice.  Should his bounty be continued to you in future you ought to be grateful for it, and should it be continued you will have no cause to complain as you have never given anything to the US. in return.  Brothers,  We wish you to let this talk sink deep into your hearts, we wish you to take time and reflect seriously on it, and when you have made up your minds we shall listen to you with pleasure

went to the Walnut Hills and the presents were but very small  I do not know whether these presents were concealed from us or not, But I know we got but few not worth going after.  A couple of the War Chiefs and Warriors recd the last spring past a few presents at the Bluffs, that is all --If there have been any others given it must have been to Idle indians who are stragling about & do not attend to the Talks of the Chief of the Nation -- There is an old boundary line between the white people and my Nation which was run before I was a Chief of the Nation.  This was run by the permission of the Chiefs of the Nation who were chiefs at that time -- They understood when that tine was run that they were to receive pay for those lands.  These Chiefs here present acknowledge the lands to be the white peoples land.  They hold no claim on it tho' they never recd any pay for it.  They wish the line to be marked anew, and that it be done by some of both parties as both should be present  I mean both red and white people -- Too,te,hoo,muh from the far District then spoke  I thank the president my father for sending you three beloved men over here to speak to me. who have delivered to us the talks of the President. I understood yesterday that my father the president allowed me an annual present, & it should never be taken from me. Oak,chume of the upper Towns then Spoke  I see you today in the shade of your own house.  I am a poor distressed red man -- I know not how to ask anything -- I am in the place here from the upper towns.  My Uncle was the Great Chief of the Nation, kept all paths clean and swept out, long poles of peau?, a number of Officers and Chiefs in his Army -- He is gone, he is dead, he has left us behind -- You three beloved even in my presence?  I am glad to see you -- -- You may be my father for what I know.  The Great Spirit above is over us all.  I hold my five fingers and with them I hold yours, mine are black, but I whiten them for the occasion --  I understood your Great father General Washington was dead and that the great council got together and appointed another in his stead, who has not forgot us and who loves us as our father Washington did and I am glad to hear our father the President wishes that the Sun may shine bright over his red Children -- The Chickasaws are my old Brothers -- you visited them and talked to them before I saw you here.  I understood you asked for a big path to be cut, a white path, a path of peace and that they granted it to you as far as their lands extended.  I grant it like wise.  There are no big water courses, there are no big rivers nor creeks and therefore no occasion for canoes, nor is there any occasion for horse boats.  It is not our wish that there should be any houses built.  The reason I give is that there is a number of young warriors

as good, and as strong as you will. -- As there are no big water courses on it, there is no occasion for Canoes or Ferries. -- I speak now concerning an old line which was run when I was a bot, I wish this line to be traced and marked anew -- I do not know where this line is -- I have been informed by some of the young men of my nation that there are white people and stock over it.  We chiefs of the Nation wish if any are over our lines, that they be moved back again by our Brothers the Officers of the U.S. and that they would move them back with their stock -- Mingo poof,coos, of the Chickasaw Hay Town Spoke thus  I am an old acquaintance here -- I came here with other Chief of the Nation not to differ with them, but to join them in whatever they may do. The day will come when we head men will see each other -- The road this our land to Tombigby it is not in any power to grant them an others Chiefs who hold dairy on those lands -- My claim is but short -- The white people travel the line of Limits between Spain & the United States -- They are free to use that and any of the small paths.

May 1802  Sir,  I had the honor to write you from the Oconee the 16th. Inst. & arrived here yesterday to explain to the Governor the views & disposition of the General government & of their commissioners for holding the pending conferences with the Creeks & at the same time to learn from him how soon the State would be prepared to cooperate with those commissioners in the proposed negotiation -- I find the Governor has issued his proclamation to convene the Legislature on the 10th of the next month which may I fear involve delays hazardous to our views as The Indians

May --1802  Sir,  We have the honor to inform you that after exhausting every plausible pretext for delay, we found ourselves compelled to commence our negotiations with the Creeks yesterday, having had no communication with the State of Georgia, except what will be found in the enclosed copy of our correspondence with Governor Tattenall --  The address under cover will exhibit to you, the great caution with which we were obliged to open our Business, to prevent irritation & alarm, & the effects of a sudden impulse.  The points prefaced to our main subject, tho' in some degree irrelative to the objects of the Commission were introduced to excite a strong sense of humil-

21  Genl Wilkinson's speech continued from page 14 -- The commissioners of the United States appointed by your father the President have this day witnessed the ceremonies of your forefathers, they have received the ceremony of respect & they acknowledge themselves obliged --  We have been appointed to brighten the chains of friendship between the red & white people of this country; we shall endeavour to take care of the interests of the white people while we shall not forget those of the red -- We have been pleased to see the the bloody arrow & tomahawk buried in the earth and we hope no occasion will ever offer to lift them again -- We view with you the blueness of the sky, the brightness of the Sun & serenity of the day as emblems favorable to a happy issue of our negotiations; whatever way may be the result we will endeavour to acquit ourselves to red men & to white men -- After being received in form, & hearing what has passed we shall be prepared to commence the great business of our mission with the shortest delay -- Your father the President has the same good will towards you that Washington had and

June 9th.  The Commissioners met the chiefs and Esau Haujo the Speaker for the Nation addressed them thus  Friends, Fathers & Brothers. --  I am going to speak to you.  You three gentlemen saw me when I was in my own land.  You saw me here, you told me that the great man to the northward gave you great talks & you have given them to us.  I mentioned when I saw you that I was old; but nevertheless we wd. talk over old things together.  I was told by you beloved men that the talk you have given us was straight & that before we parted every thing would be straight on both sides.  According to what has passed between us about the business, we have come forward & today am going to talk about the same.  I was told that when all things were made straight, it wd. be for the happiness & tend to prolong the safety of the red people.  The intention of the talk I will give you is this, that I hope what

vide for the wants of his white children & at the same time to secure his red children a permanent income, more valuable to them than hunting & traping, which will last as long as the grass grows, & assist them ti increase their stock, to promote their domestic manufactures & extend their agricultural pursuits as well as to insure the remainder of their extended Nation forever.  In short to make them useful to Themselves & to mankind happy in their condition & independent of the world. --  We are your friends, we have told you so before & you must believe us.  We have given our attention to these propositions, we have considered them well, & we recommend to you to indulge the desires of your Father the President, who has your good & the good of your whole Nation at Heart.  We have nothing further to say at the time -- We desire you to take this talk into your your serious deliberations & to consider it well before you give us an answer; in the mean time we shall be ready to counsel and to advise you should you request it --  /true copy  Andew Pickens Junr

upon it --  When a man has a child he considers him & is not willing to distress him & make him poor.  I mentioned this before & I mention it again.  I hope what we do, tho' it is not as much as was asked & expected yet will be thought sufficient -- (I hope it will be considered as it is & altho' it is not what was asked, yet it will suffice for the present demands, we now give on paper / delivering the map / what we mean & intend;  it is a map of the country we cede ---  I have now some few things more to say. I hope it will be considered it is not right to make us too poor & that it will not be thought hard that we parted with no more, we can lye down & enjoy what we have, altho' it is but little we may resat on it --  I have been told our people are very mad, they are so, but we are not the only mad people; the white people come over

I now say will be beneficial to all old & young when I am dead & gone, this is my intention & this will be the drift of my speech --   I address myself to the gentlemen appointed to speak to us to let them know our poverty & distress & I hope they will think think what I do will be right & acceptable.  I have been talked to a great deal before I could lift up my head, but now I can lift up my head & look up.  The thing that was asked us to part with, was like asking us to cut ourselves in two & take one half one way and  the other half the other way.  I was told by the great Men who were appointed to bring us the talk of the Great Man, that they hoped we would not throw his talk away.  You see my situation, I am poor, & I consider that I have made myself very poor in complying; yet I have considered it & I have done it --  I saw the great complaints which hang over our Land, they have been laid before us, we have considered them as they are -- Upon the talk you gave us we have considered much. preserve good neighbourhood & that they will exert themselves to that end.  I consider it in this light, that the heads of the white people who can govern their people, should take the necessary precautions on their part to keep their young people in bounds & we will do the same on our part as well as we can -- When Ocohee was made the line the River was the bounds for stock, we were told, in Mr Seagrove's time, if hunters came over we might take their guns if trappers came we might take their traps & if cattle came over we might drive them off; we have not done these things, we wanted to be in peace & friendship with our neighbours & therefore we have not done these things, and we have submitted to the loss of our grass & game to be at peace with our friends --  This is not all, it is not here only but in Cumberland they have large dogs & horses and they come out there & hunt or drive off the Bear before our hunters get there -- Our faults were mentioned, we must mention our complaints against our neighbours -- I have talked of these things to Colo

over & hunt on our lands some with fire & some with fire arms & the cattle they are over & have eaten all the food of our black game (bear)  We were told that people were set to prevent it & protect our rights; but they can not prevent these things --  They are over & we see they cannot be prevented -- The President of the U.S. who sent these talks we hope & expect gave you full powers & that you will as formerly endeavour to put things in force to prevent these things before there is an end to our business --  What I speak in time for us, I see where there was, a river people could not be restrained & now when there is no water boundary they will perhaps act as they have done, they have stoped our creeks with fish traps & also our part of the River the cut Cedar on Ockmulgee -- at other places. --  The fish & terrapins in Ockmulgee are ours & we wish they may remain to our use.   Why I say so much on this subject is that I know the past, & I wish to begin in time to prevent the consequences which I apprehend.  I speak that the whitest Indians may equally take farms in a gentle manner & by gentle means

must be many white people unknown to us, who have stock among us, when they come after it we wish to assist them by signs and otherwise to get their property if they cannot talk our language. -- -- -- After a conference with the Chiefs Esau Haujo speaks again ---  This day is appointed to consider our distressed situation and to remove all difficulties.  This day the land under us we have given up, the trees around us, the water fine for Mills, good land & a great deal of it.  The good that will arise from the land will have no end --  in the Summers there will be the grass for stocks, & other things in the winter; I consider these things & I have given them up. --  The way of the Red is this:  they are a poor people, if there be any oak trees they get acorns from them & from hickory trees they get hickory nuts, & the black berries in their season --  I address myself to Colonel Hawkins & I find the white people do the same, they suppose you favor the Red people, but we believe you hide nothing from either side & you are the friend of

Hawkins & I am sure he has sent them on and I now address them to General Wilkinson who is a great Man and commands many -- I hope he will assist us & help us to get redress.  I give this warning because I know Cattles and Horses know not lines and will go after grass.  When a man goes after his horse or cow, let him take a bridle and go after it, if it is on our land; but he must go without a gun -- -- I hear that here when the line is known the people come over it a day's walk to good food, and there give salt to their stock, they also take out their hogs with corn & leave them in every part of our borders --  By carrying their stock out so far they accustom them to go still farther, they get lost & then the Indians are blamed for stealing them.  some times they have seen horses out for ten months as strays & The Indians are accused of stealing them --  I wish that the white people would keep their stocks as much as possible on their own side & endeavour to induce them to stay on their own side --  If cattle go over the line we wish they may be returned in peace, that horses, hogs & every thing may be returned in like manner.  There

a greater necessity for the aid of the Military. Perhaps you may want to run your line now offered immediately -- if so we will approve four Men from each town to run it with you, we mention this as perhaps you may think that Man / meaning Bowles / may do something to prevent it --Here you may See the inconvenience from drinking yourselves & we without young people may have no temptation to go among the white people for drink; but be confined to their trading places. The commissioners & chiefs assembled, Esau Haujo addressed the Commissioners as follows:  My Fathers & Brothers -- -- You are all before me, this is the last time I shall address you.  I speak to you in friendship & in earnest & my talk is a sincere one.  My talk is in this live I am a sufferer & expect I shall be considered as such.  I hope you will consider me so & that you will not turn my talks aside or consider them as trifling.  The people are poor & the reason I talk so much upon the subject is because I wish you to consider us so --  You have seen me my country & my people & I hope the President may see my talks as they are delivered, that in future we may not be pressed upon -- It must be considered in this way that we have spared that which is necessary to us & we have not enough for our own use -- (As we are the Aborigines in this Land, we hope it will be

Natchez; all who go with families should be directed to that path, to prevent a breach of the peace & to preserve it --  I this day have the Commissioners before me, I address myself to them on this subject. I do not love?? the sense here is keep out or bar my land from people who are coming after cattle, horses or hogs or to trade with us or single persons coming with papers on business.  I confine myself to families moving with their property, these I object to -- (I take upon myself to speak to the Quakers, I have found that the tools they have sent us as a token of their friendship have been useful to us & we are better able to judge now than when we received them, as we have tried them them & found them useful to us. Treaty into effect.  If a white man, as Factor or Trader, should take any goods from the United States or from Spain to the Nation, there must be a rule by which they are to be punished --  and the regulation must be in force till the Nation give satisfaction in the case complained of.  We blame not the White people we blame ourselves, & this is to remain Law, until the Nation comply with the Treaty Stipulations --  When we have done this the doors must be opened & let trade take its course  This is a Law we have now made and it must be sent to the Cherokees, Chickasaws & the Choctaws that they may know it --  And it is our Law that these nations shall not supply any goods to a Creek.  Now Cherokees our brothers, some of our people are running to you for trade, you must put a stop to it as well as the United States & Spain.  The same we address to the Chickasaws and Choctaws --  Justunnugge Thlacco,   This Law is for the People on this side of the line of Limits, as for those of Spain they are for themselves, if they make war let them see to it --

among us, & we wish one price for these things could be found at the Factories --  Another thing they mention is what I have seen myself since I came here, the goods have risen in price, can it be that they are small things growing out of the ground, & as such we purchased them when we came, and they have now grown larger & a price accordingly appears on the same things --  I am now about to speak on another subject --  The Last Treaty at Colerain, some articles of which are not yet fulfilled, I am now going to make an effort to progress, I have not the power to lift up an arrow against our neighbouring towns -- we consider that after this Treaty, when we go home we will try to put inforce our warriors, there are a good many towns present who speak upon it, there is another way to fulfill the promise of the Old Treaty -- There are but two keys, the United States have one in a Store & Spain has the other now in Pensacala, these two keys may lock the doors & be put in the pocket -- I do not say in how many Months or how many Years, it can be done, but then the Door shall be opened -- It is to be left to me to order the Door to be opened as soon as we have done our business by carrying the

Esau Haujo --  There is a proviso in our Law; people in debt may go & pay their debts & if they have a balance due them let them take money or due bills & keep them until a regular trade is restored.  This law is passed by our own chiefs, if injury is done to any one, we are to feel the misery of it ourselves from a want of trade.  I think my talks have been extended as far as in my power to preserve peace --  I hope that you Coln Hawkins will first put it inforce by sending it to the Agents of the other three Nations & assist us in carrying it into effect and see to the execution of it until our object is effected --  As this is the finishing of the talk I have to regret that our women with their hoes are behind, that they & their children are likely to have poverty and hunger for their lot.  I consider all this & it is my care, it presses hard on my mind.  I consider it so, that I have done all I can to Save my Land --  I wish in Three days at farther to try & set out, that we may not entirely lose our crops & all suffer with hunger --  This is the end of my talk -- and I hope it will be for the benefit of all when we are dead and gone -- Andw Pickens Jr  / true copy /
